@La__Cuen @NelsonMRosario @stephendpalley @prestonjbyrne The current financial anticrime regime is not about "follow these rules" the way other laws/regulations typically \nare. @naval This is why we use Occam's Razor. Not because simpler theories are more likely to be true, but because simpler theories teach us more when they turn out to be false.

@naval Suppose our model makes predictions which then turn out to be wrong. Can this teach us which of its assumptions were more wrong? Then it's a good (simple) model. Good models are ones that serve us even well when they turn out to be wrong.

@patio11 Again, to be clear, I don't think NYT did that because they wanted to mislead me. I think they did it because they wanted Trump not to win. But it doesn't matter why they did it. The fact is, trusting them made you wronger, even though what they wrote was all correct.

@patio11 I learned this when Trump won. I mentally reviewed all the detailed, accurate, credibly-sourced, fact-checked material that NYT had published that had convinced me there was absolutely no way that Trump could win. I realized I had swallowed a falsehood built out of 100% truths.

@patio11 As a thought experiment, suppose you give the test group a subscription to the WSJ or the NYT, and you give the control group no such subscription, and then after an exposure period you see which group makes better predictions or actions.
@patio11 (Also, a lot of people ‚Äî although not, IMHO WSJ, and NYT ‚Äî *are* using this same pattern to intentionally mislead people without saying anything untrue, unsourced, etc.)

@patio11 I don't mean to accuse them of deliberately lying, I just mean to dramatize the fact that the modern journalistic practice that you so aptly summarize in that tweet is insufficient if your goal is to have a better understanding of the world.
@patio11 I've been thinking a lot about this. You can build a lie out of 100% truths.

5. Wear a mask

This is the thing that everyone knows helps, except for the untrustworthy World Health Organization.
These are four things that most people (excepting Italians) know are good for your community.

1. Practice ‚Äúsocial distancing‚Äù (I.e. physical distancing ‚Äî stay 6 feet apart)
2. Wash hands
3. Don‚Äôt attend gatherings, crowded places, restaurants. Replace in-person meetings and social visits with remote.
4. Exercise outdoors every day.
Things to do to help protect your community from covid-19:

What I wish they understood is that it *isn‚Äôt* that in all those other places with the opposite social norms it is considered okay to put society at risk ‚Äî it is that outdoor exercise is believed to *help* society by *protecting people‚Äôs health* without spreading disease.

@TripsCrypto @ask_aristarchus @chris_fec This illustrates how a major source of data leakage ‚Äî in Zcash, in other cybercoins, and in non-blockchain apps ‚Äî is the network layer and we need to improve that. Already today Alice could use Tor, which could help.

@TripsCrypto @ask_aristarchus @chris_fec ... But look out for off-chain data leakage! If Mallory can spy on the network level messages, which any sophisticated adversary can do today, then she might be able to figure out which IP address generated the 7-utxo shielded transaction!

@TripsCrypto @ask_aristarchus @chris_fec ... From looking only at the blockchain data, all Mallory sees is that someone made a transaction with seven z-utxos in it. She doesn't learn anything else, and using blockchain data alone, she can't distinguish Example D from Example A. ...

@TripsCrypto @ask_aristarchus @chris_fec 4 Example D Alice sends to herself.  After receiving the dust, then Alice sends some money to herself. @TripsCrypto @ask_aristarchus @chris_fec reporting whoever makes a deposit with seven z-utxos in it. Unless one of the other three factors above prevents it, this would link Alice's Bible-sales zaddr with Alice's exchange account.

@TripsCrypto @ask_aristarchus @chris_fec ... Alice is illegally selling Bibles in China and depositing the proceeds into an exchange. Mallory‚Äîwho works for the Chinese anti-Bible police‚Äîsends dust to the zaddr of the mysterious Bible seller and then strongarms the exchange into...

@TripsCrypto @ask_aristarchus @chris_fec 4 Example C What if Mallory knows Alice's zaddr but doesn't know who owns that zaddr and wants to de-anonymize them, and *Alice send a transaction to Mallory*? This is a very powerful and surprisingly common threat model. For example, ...

@TripsCrypto @ask_aristarchus @chris_fec ... the zaddr that she previously dusted with this particular public donation, including what charity it went to and how much it was. So the "I dusted that zaddr with seven zutxos" is now linked to a whole bunch more information than in Example A.

@TripsCrypto @ask_aristarchus @chris_fec 4 Example B. What if Mallory dusts Alice's zaddr, and then Alice makes a z2t transaction, for example donating to a public charity's taddr? Then (unless one of the other three factors upthread intervenes), Mallory can link ...
@TripsCrypto @ask_aristarchus @chris_fec ... that a seven-utxo transaction was posted to the blockchain and that she previously dusted Alice with seven zutxos.

@TripsCrypto @ask_aristarchus @chris_fec ... She knows that Alice made a transaction (unless one of the 3 other factors up-thread prevent her from even being able to tell that), but she can't see to whom it went (that's shielded), or anything else about it. All Mallory knows is ...

‚Ä¶ other than that it must have been worth at least 10,000 as much as the miner ultimately received.

A zero-knowledge proof could demonstrate to all miners that the amount that went to the miner was the right amount, based on a random beacon, but it wouldn‚Äôt reveal anything about how much you got back, or how much was the value of the ZEC in the transaction, ‚Ä¶

Later, once the transaction finalizes on the blockchain, you get a (shielded) rebate, giving you a random amount of your Max Fee back (privately), and the miner who mined your transaction gets the rest.

When you make a transaction, you have to provide Max Fee ZEC as a fee with your transaction, but you do so under encryption, inside the shielding, so that nobody other than you and the recipient of your payment know the Max Fee and the amount of value being transferred.
Suppose the ‚ÄúMax Fee‚Äù fee for a transaction is equal to a fixed proportion of the value of the transaction, such as 1/10,000‚Äôth of the value of the transaction.

So is it possible to make miner/staker fees be proportional to the amount of value transferred *without* revealing the amount of transferred? Nathan Wilcox (Zcash architect and Electric Coin Co CTO) and I were talking about that today and here‚Äôs a sketch of an idea:

That‚Äôs why we built optional shielded transactions into the Zcash blockchain from the beginning. We think mandatorily having to reveal the amount of ZEC in each transaction is a non-starter for security.

We believe that going forward, leakage of that much sensitive information will turn out to be incompatible with business security requirements, national security, and laws and norms, not to mention personal privacy and safety.

‚Ä¶ if you make the fee be a fixed proportion to the amount transferred‚Äîlike the fee is always equal to 1/10,000 of the amount of ZEC being transferred‚Äîthen people would be able to tell how much ZEC you were transferring, even if the transfer is inside a shielded transaction.
But, the fee paid to the miner is visible to the public (since anyone can be a miner), and ‚Ä¶

Perhaps it could help with the long-term conundrum of whether it is possible to continue getting blockchain security without perpetually issuing more new tokens ‚Äî a conundrum that Bitcoin and Zcash don‚Äôt yet have a convincing answer to.
Making the fees proportional to the value might help buttress security even if there is only one asset, such as the current Zcash blockchain, where there is only ZEC.
‚Ä¶ the amount of fees they get is proportional to the amount of value users are transacting on the blockchain.

One thing that might help is if the fee paid to the miners was proportional to the value being transferred. This could at least partially restore the reasoning that miners/stakers are incentivized to provide good service because ‚Ä¶
Some people think this "Top Heavy Problem" could happen to ETH-vs-ERC-20‚Äôs and could happen to tokenized securities on a public blockchain.

‚Ä¶ to play by the rules because of their rewards. Potentially this could undermine security of the entire blockchain. A similar argument can be made for developers and other core support functions being funded by the blockchain, as is done in Zcash.

If the value of the assets riding on top of the blockchain become much more valuable than the asset used to reward miners/stakers, developers and core support functions, etc, then we can no longer rely on the reasoning that miners/stakers are incentivized ‚Ä¶

But even if adding User-Defined Assets on top of Zcash wouldn‚Äôt help Zcash, would it at least be harmless? Unfortunately, it might actually be harmful! There‚Äôs this problem that some people call ‚ÄúThe Top-Heavy Problem‚Äù.

Billions of dollars worth of Tether is in circulation, with tens of billions of dollars per day of transactions, but Mastercoin is worthless, which means there is no further maintenance, support, or improvement for Mastercoin. https://t.co/gslPZHcPNA

There‚Äôs an argument that this wouldn‚Äôt be good for the value of ZEC, and by extension wouldn‚Äôt be good for the maintenance and improvement of the Zcash blockchain. Nic Carter wrote a great analysis of the history of Mastercoin, which Tether was built on top of.
But would that be good or bad for Zcash?
potentially in the future side-chaining with other blockchains, etc.

It would allow arbitrary new tokens to be issued on the Zcash blockchain and to take advantage of Zcash‚Äôs features: a widely-used and highly resilient decentralized blockchain, shielded transactions, selective transparency, the encrypted memo field, ...
It would be interesting to have User-Defined Assets on top of Zcash ‚Äî like ERC-20 tokens.
